Hello, 

My cluster is using version 1.1.3 and I have plenty of vector documents stored in there for my app. However there are memory issues that my cluster is experiencing and trying to update collection to use disk space instead of memory does not work on such version. I'm thinking of updating to latest 1.7.4 is there any precautions I can do to make sure migration goes well and no data will be lost?

In my application, content is organized into groups, and each user can be a member of virtually any number of groups, although for the purpose of this discussion, let's set a limit of 10K groups.

Each group typically contains between 1K and 50K documents, with the majority having fewer than 5K. The overall number of documents in the system is approximately 250M. Importantly, each document is associated with only one group, and the payload includes a group ID, for example: {..., "group_id": 12345, ...}.

When conducting a search on behalf of a user, our goal is to retrieve documents whose vectors closely match a given vector, but exclusively from groups to which the user belongs.

So if we will blindly construct a query to obtain the necessary data, the filter section of this query could potentially contain up to 10K clauses
For example in "filter"."should" array:
"should": [
        { "key": "group_id", "match": { "value": 111222 } },
        { "key": "group_id", "match": { "value": 12346 } },
        ... (10,000 more values here) ...,
        { "key": "group_id", "match": { "value": 32145715 } }
 ]
Or in "key"."match"."any" array:
{
  "key": "group_id",
  "match": {
    "any": ["111222", "12346", ...10K more values here..., "32145715"]
  }
}

My questions are:
1. Will this even work, and are there any limitations regarding the number of clauses?
2. What kind of performance penalty can I expect with this method?
3. How does performance decline as the number of values increases? Is there a linear penalty in some worst-case scenario?

You also have `memmap_threshold: 20000` configured, which would put vectors on disk when they surpass the 20 megabyte threshold. If you'd be wondering whether it's possible to provide all our endpoints over a single port; then no, that's not possible.
You may be able to use it in some very specific use case, but we definitely don't recommend this.
Yes. With that limitation you'd never be able to make full and proper use of Qdrant.

Am I right that you currently have (had) `max_indexing_threads` at a value like `1000`?

That's a humongous number, and can definitely cause weird behavior.

I'm basing that off the thread here: https://discord.com/channels/907569970500743200/1200195768561184798
We generally recommend to keep the default values for those parameters.

>  also what factors trigger the optmisation? is it time related or is it related to any parameters in optimization config?
It's purely parameters in the optimization config.
To answer your question regarding CPU/RAM usage. The higher all of these numbers are, the more CPU/RAM may be consumed during optimizations.
For your information, we're making some internal changes to automatically select the best configuration for your machine, without having to configure anything.

Here are some good examples:

- If your CPU has <= 16 threads (cores)
  - `max_indexing_threads: 0`
  - `max_optimization_threads: 1`
- If your CPU has <= 32 threads
  - `max_indexing_threads: 0`
  - `max_optimization_threads: 2`
- If your CPU has <= 64 threads
  - `max_indexing_threads: 0`
  - `max_optimization_threads: 4`
...

> Currently, in my collection, I've configured "max_indexing_threads" as 1000 and "max_optimization_threads" as 1. During collection optimization (yellow state), there is a noticeable spike in CPU and RAM usage. Could you please explain how modifying these configuration values will impact the utilization of RAM and CPU?
First of all, we definitely do not recommend setting `max_indexing_threads: 1000`. That is a super high number.

In fact, we recommend to set it at 16, and not higher. The reason for that is, that higher numbers generate less accurate indexes.
If you have more than 16 threads on your CPU, you can do more of these indexing operations in parallel for which you can increase `max_optimization_threads`.

>  Hi, How does auto selection works for max_indexing_threads?
It depends on what version of Qdrant you're using.
Are you using Qdrant 1.7? Then it defaults to 16 threads. If your CPU has less threads available, it'll use that number instead.

> To do that we need to scan the vectordb payload/metadata in order to figure out if the document in the repository is newer, hence the response time for this operation is critical.
Could you describe your exact requirements a bit better? Maybe it's worth giving the `scroll`  API a go to see if it satisfies your needs.

> Even on search operations, all queries are usually filtered by 2 or more metadata.
This is totally fine.

For use cases like this it is probably better to have a second database next to Qdrant, which you use for tracking IDs and their expiry times. This could be any relational database such as MySQL for example.
You easily find the expired IDs in here, and keep using Qdrant for the actual vector search part of this problem.

Qdrant does have a scroll API, which you can use to find points without a vector but with some filter:
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/points/#scroll-points

This call _can_ be rather inefficient though, as it tries to go over all points you have. I think you _could_ also do a regular vector search with an all zero vector to make use of the fast HNSW graph. That may not have 100% accuracy though.

Let me detail the use case.
We have about 15.000 large documents chunked into 1M+ vectors. We store a few metadata as these documents have complex expiry dates.
Before expiry, we need to get the updated document, delete these old record from the DB and replace it by the updated version.
Due to the unpredictable date at which an update is published (within 1 month before expiry), we regularly scan the document repository and then check the db if what we have in it is current or if the document is newer, triggering the update process.
The full 15.000 docs are replaced every quarter.

To do that we need to scan the vectordb payload/metadata in order to figure out if the document in the repository is newer, hence the response time for this operation is critical.

Even on search operations, all queries are usually filtered by 2 or more metadata.

Does that answer your question somewhat?
It may only touch disk to fetch the full payload for the points that were found while searching. But the extra time that takes is probably insignificant.

Note that IF payload data is on disk, it is usually stored in RocksDB. It's an embeddable database we use for this. 
Normally, this should not be accessed while searching.
I'd recommend to give Qdrant a spin with your data set, if possible. That's the best way to evaluate whether you meet your performance requirements.

The important thing here is to create indexes for specific payload fields you query. In Qdrant, we integrate indexed payload keys into our HNSW graph for vectors. That way we guarantee the best performance and the best accuracy.
We store vectors and payload data separately. Depending on how you configure your collection, your actual data may be in different places.
We don't really use ways of a traditional relational database with tables to store data, so I don't think that analogy works with Qdrant.

content: I hope that answers your questions üòÑ

To clarify, a green collection status means that everything has already been put on disk. So nothing to worry there! Again, memory usage is so high because even though data is on disk, Qdrant will still try to fill as much memory as possible, but without OOMing.
A green collection status means that there are currently no optimizations running/scheduled. So yes, that can be expected üëç
So even if you'd insert or remove points, the memory usage will likely hover around the same amount, which is expected.
This follow the mantra: _Unused memory is wasted memory_
This should be safe however. If there's something else that needs memory, Qdrant will automatically release some memory to allow this.
In that case, Qdrant will keep trying to use as much memory as possible in an attempt to serve results as fast as possible.

Yes. More specifically, Qdrant normalizes cosine vectors, not others.
qdrant returns already normalized vectors, so your formula is equal np.dot(vec1, norm_vec2) / (norm_vec1 * norm_vec2)

Here's a code snippet. 
`qdrant` is my own libary that I wrapped around `qdrant` python client.

I first call a recommend API  (with some payload filter and limit to top 30 recommendations), I then get the points of the result recommendation back from qdrant. I then compute the cosine distance and compare the ranking in another function `log_similarity`. 
```
res = qdrant.recommend(id,point['lang'],30)
res_ids = [item['id'] for item in res]
res_points = qdrant.get_points(res_ids, with_payload=True, with_vectors=True)
log_similarity(point, res_points) 
```
Below are the function
```
def cosine_similarity(vec1, vec2):
  """
  Compute the cosine similarity between two vectors
  """
  dot_product = np.dot(vec1, vec2)
  norm_vec1 = np.linalg.norm(vec1)
  norm_vec2 = np.linalg.norm(vec2)
  
  similarity = dot_product / (norm_vec1 * norm_vec2)
  
  return similarity

def log_similarity(point, res_points):
    # compute the similarity
    similarities = []
    index = 0
    for r in res_points:
      similarity = cosine_similarity(point['content_embeddings'], r['content_embeddings'])
      logging.info("Distance between %s and %s: %s", point['id'], r['id'], similarity)
      similarities.append((index, point['id'], similarity))
      index += 1
      
    # sort the similarities ascending
    similarities.sort(key=lambda x: x[2])
    
    # log the similarities
    logging.info("Sorted by distance ascending")
    for similarity in similarities:
      logging.info("Similarity: %s", similarity)
```

Hi

TL;DR It's ok, you just have many segments and not that much data

Qdrant itself does not produce embeddings, in general, it's the user's responsibility to produce embeddings (however Qdrant has a tool for generating embeddings, later about it)

Qdrant searches in a vector space (i.e. via embeddings). I.e. to perform search in Qdrant, you need to pass an embedding in a search query and it will look for similar embeddings in the vector space.

All the text information is stored in payload. Payload can be used to add some additional filters to your search queries.

Qdrant has a tool https://github.com/qdrant/fastembed which can be used to a ease the process of inserting data to qdrant.
All you need to do is to install python qdrant-client with a fastembed dependency and certain methods like `add` and `query` in qdrant-client

Methods like `add` and `query` accepts texts as input, then fastembed generates embeddings and puts them into qdrant

List of available models can be found here https://qdrant.github.io/fastembed/examples/Supported_Models/

referenced_message.content:
Hi

Could you please elaborate on the task you want to solve?

There are two different ways to leverage full-text search in Qdrant

The first one is to use sparse vectors index 

You can read about it here

https://qdrant.tech/articles/sparse-vectors/

and here

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/indexing/?selector=aHRtbCA%2BIGJvZHkgPiBkaXY6bnRoLW9mLXR5cGUoMSkgPiBzZWN0aW9uID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2Om50aC1vZi10eXBlKDIpID4gYXJ0aWNsZSA%2BIGgyOm50aC1vZi10eXBlKDMp#sparse-vector-index

You can have both dense (semantic) embeddings and sparse (full-text) embeddings in one collection

The second one is not actually a genuine full-text search, but an enhancement to a semantic search. You can apply full-text match filters to your semantic search queries to find records which are both closest to your query + satisfies additional conditions.

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/filtering/?selector=aHRtbCA%2BIGJvZHkgPiBkaXY6bnRoLW9mLXR5cGUoMSkgPiBzZWN0aW9uID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2Om50aC1vZi10eXBlKDIpID4gYXJ0aWNsZSA%2BIGgzOm50aC1vZi10eXBlKDEwKQ%3D%3D#full-text-match

content:
If they are in the same collection, you can just put all of them into `requests` param like this

```python
search_queries = [
    models.SearchRequest(vector=vector_1, filter=filter_1, limit=3),
models.SearchRequest(vector=vector_1, filter=filter_2, limit=3),
    models.SearchRequest(vector=vector_2, filter=filter_1, limit=3),
    models.SearchRequest(vector=vector_2, filter=filter_2, limit=3),
]

client.search_batch(collection_name="{collection_name}", requests=search_queries)
```

Hi

Could you please elaborate on the task you want to solve?

There are two different ways to leverage full-text search in Qdrant

The first one is to use sparse vectors index 

You can read about it here

https://qdrant.tech/articles/sparse-vectors/

and here

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/indexing/?selector=aHRtbCA%2BIGJvZHkgPiBkaXY6bnRoLW9mLXR5cGUoMSkgPiBzZWN0aW9uID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2Om50aC1vZi10eXBlKDIpID4gYXJ0aWNsZSA%2BIGgyOm50aC1vZi10eXBlKDMp#sparse-vector-index

You can have both dense (semantic) embeddings and sparse (full-text) embeddings in one collection

The second one is not actually a genuine full-text search, but an enhancement to a semantic search. You can apply full-text match filters to your semantic search queries to find records which are both closest to your query + satisfies additional conditions.

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/filtering/?selector=aHRtbCA%2BIGJvZHkgPiBkaXY6bnRoLW9mLXR5cGUoMSkgPiBzZWN0aW9uID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2Om50aC1vZi10eXBlKDIpID4gYXJ0aWNsZSA%2BIGgzOm50aC1vZi10eXBlKDEwKQ%3D%3D#full-text-match

content:
Hello! I'm new to Qdrant and trying to understand how it works in terms of querying and answering. Specifically, since Qdrant takes vectors but can provide string-like answers, could someone explain the communication process between search API and Qdrant in simple terms? 
Does Qdrant do its own embeddings, and if so, what kind of embedding model does it use? Thanks!

Hi

It's not absolutely clear how to interpret your question, first of all, I assume that you are using Qdrant

Each point in Qdrant has 3 main fields: id, vector, payload
There are two ways how you can use chunk_id

1) use it as point id
2) put it into payload (the usual way)

1) If you use chunk_id as point.id, then you can simply use upsert method.  When you insert a point with id which is already present in Qdrant, it overwites it.

2) In case you store chunk id in payload
You can use `scroll` method with a filter to retrieve point by chunk_id, it will return you a point which contains id

Then you need to take point.id and upsert point with updated info

I think it will be the fastest way in your case

If you want to update only vector, or only payload, you can use methods update_vectors or set_payload (or overwrite_payload)

You can find points documentation here https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/points/

Came up with this, it works but feels hacky, if there is any other way let me know.
model.MatchAny won't allow anything but ints.

def search(vector , keywords , top=10):

    concepts = list(set([keyword['concept'] for keyword in keywords]))
    instances = list(set([keyword['instance'] for keyword in keywords]))

    values = client.search(
        "test_collection", 
        query_vector=vector , 
        search_params=models.SearchParams(exact=False), 
        limit=top,
        query_filter=models.Filter(
        must=[models.FieldCondition(key="keywords[].concept", match=models.MatchAny(any=concepts)),
              models.FieldCondition(key="keywords[].instance", match=models.MatchAny(any=instances))]
        )
    )

content: custom scoring function function is indeed out of scope for qdrant. In fact, the best practice for introducing expernal parameters into semantic similarity is to use some re-ranking model. If you will try to just manually tune coefficients, it is a very easy way to shoot your own leg
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/collections/#collection-with-multiple-vectors
